repnme.cdata!: Bangladesh - Third Inland Water Transport Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is adjudged
            satisfactory, although there were inordinate delays in
            implementing the operational improvement and financial
            recovery plans of the executing agencies. Project
            sustainability is unlikely basically because the Government
            of Bangladesh's commitment to pursue much broader
            policy and institutional reforms, including divestiture,
            appears weak. Overall World Bank performance was
            satisfactory, while Borrower performance was unsatisfactory
            since it failed to achieve most of the important reform
            objectives. Lessons learned included the need to plan reform
            programs through a participatory process; to actively
            involve senior officials and closely monitor project
            implementation; to reduce delays in approval of procurement
            related activities by increasing the financial authority of
            the parastatals; to enhance the role of the private sector;
            and to engage the government in activities prior to Credit
            approval which would cement its commitment to reform, such
            as its taking irreversible actions like enacting legislation
            prior to effectiveness.

18155818.theme: Pollution management and environmental health,Rural services and infrastructure
18155818.trustfund:
TF020460-NORWEGIAN CONSULTANTS TRUST FUND,TF026800-PHRD-THIRD INLAND WATER
            TRANSPORT PROJECT,TF031190-BANGLADESH - TRANSPORT
18155818.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Rural development

repnme.cdata!: Bangladesh - Third Inland Water Transport Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project objectives are to improve
            inland water transport operations and the effectiveness of
            sector agencies.  The project consists of:  (a) an
            institution building component which will enhance the
            capacities of (i) the Department of Shipping to implement
            safety and pollution control regulations, including
            environmental monitoring of dredging, and to train inland
            vessel operations, (ii) the Bangladesh Inland Water
            Transport Authority (BIWTA) to improve its planning function
            and operations, and (iii) Bangladesh Inland Water Transport
            Corporation to restructure its fleet, organization,
            personnel, and finances; (b) a vessel safety improvement
            component which includes (i) implementation of minimum
            navigation standards for day and night navigation on Class I
            & II waterways, and (ii) upgrading of high frequency
            communications systems and establishment of 24-hour distress
            frequency monitoring at Chittagong, Dhaka and Mongla; (c) an
            inland ports component to provide 100 launch landing
            pontoons in rural areas; (d) a waterways development
            component which includes (i) dredging to improve waterway
            access to the northeast and to Baghabari Port in the
            northwest, (ii) hydrographic survey equipment, and (iii)
            support equipment to improve productivity of BIWTA's
            existing dredging fleet; and (e) a country boat component to
            provide extension services to the country boat sector.
